<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_connection_set_initial_state_:
```c
void
MHD_connection_set_initial_state_ (struct MHD_Connection *c)
{
  size_t read_buf_size;

#ifdef HTTPS_SUPPORT
  mhd_assert ( (0 == (c->daemon->options & MHD_USE_TLS)) || \
               (MHD_TLS_CONN_INIT == c->tls_state) );
  mhd_assert ( (0 != (c->daemon->options & MHD_USE_TLS)) || \
               (MHD_TLS_CONN_NO_TLS == c->tls_state) );
#endif /* HTTPS_SUPPORT */
  mhd_assert (MHD_CONNECTION_INIT == c->state);

  c->keepalive = MHD_CONN_KEEPALIVE_UNKOWN;
  c->event_loop_info = MHD_EVENT_LOOP_INFO_READ;

  memset (&c->rq, 0, sizeof(c->rq));
  memset (&c->rp, 0, sizeof(c->rp));

  c->write_buffer = NULL;
  c->write_buffer_size = 0;
  c->write_buffer_send_offset = 0;
  c->write_buffer_append_offset = 0;

  c->continue_message_write_offset = 0;

  c->read_buffer_offset = 0;
  read_buf_size = c->daemon->pool_size / 2;
  c->read_buffer
    = MHD_pool_allocate (c->pool,
                         read_buf_size,
                         false);
  c->read_buffer_size = read_buf_size;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: Rule 21.17 concerns use of string.h functions that can write/read beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters. In this function the only string.h function used is memset, in two calls: memset(&c->rq, 0, sizeof(c->rq)); and memset(&c->rp, 0, sizeof(c->rp));. Each call passes the address of the exact object being sized with sizeof that same object, so the size argument matches the object size and cannot cause an out‑of‑bounds access. No other <string.h> functions (memcpy, memmove, memset other than the two shown, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, strspn, etc.) are present in the fragment. Therefore there are no code fragments here that need investigation for Rule 21.17.
